Chapter on Chanda and Others Returning

At that time, MahÄprajÄpatÄ« and GautamÄ« saw the bright pearl in the prince's topknot, the umbrella, the cross-sword, the maá¹‡i jewel, the fly-whisk adorned with ornaments, and the other necklaces, as well as Kanthaka the horse and Chanda and the others. Having seen this, they were greatly shocked and frightened. Each raised their two hands, beat their bodies, and asked Chanda with sorrow:
Where did my beloved son SiddhÄrtha stay?
You have returned by yourself.
Chanda replied:
Great queen of the country!

Prince SiddhÄrtha abandoned the five desires and left home to enter the mountains to seek the Way. He distanced himself from his relatives, shaved his head, dyed his robes, and contemplated ascetic practices.
When MahÄprajÄpatÄ« heard these words from Chandaka, she was like a cow who has lost her calf, crying and wailing uncontrollably.
When MahÄprajÄpatÄ« heard the prince's words from Chandaka, it was also like this. She raised both hands, her heart shocked and torn, and cried out loudly:ğŸ”½Alas, my son!
Alas, my son!
Tears filled her face, her whole body trembled, and she suddenly fainted. Her body collapsed and rolled in the dirt, like a fish out of water writhing in agony on land.
MahÄprajÄpatÄ« was also like this. She fell to the ground, rolling and sobbing. She asked Chandaka, saying:
Chandaka!
I do not see any faults in my body or mistakes in my words and mind. I have not wronged you. Why have you suddenly abandoned my son, throwing him away in the wilderness like a piece of wood?

You have placed my son in that forest, leaving him alone amidst various evil beasts and terrifying creatures. You have abandoned him and come back without any pity for my son, turning your back on him?
Channa replied:
Great queen!
I did not dare abandon the prince.
Queen!
The prince himself abandoned me.

The prince entrusted me with Kanthaka, the king of horses, and various ornaments, instructing me to return quickly to the palace, fearing that the great queen would give rise to sorrow, so that she may be at ease and free from distress.
At that time, the palace ladies each cried out in their mouths, lamenting:
Alas, father!
Some also cried out:ğŸ”½Alas, mother!
'Alas, brothers!'
Some cried out:
'Alas, my master!'
Some cried out:
'Alas, my husband!'
With these various sorrowful cries of affection, the root of desire, they lamented in pain.

Some court ladies cried with rolling eyes, some cried looking at each other, some cried turning their bodies, some cried raising their heads, some cried observing each other's faces, some cried slapping their bellies with both hands, some cried patting their hearts with both hands, some cried with their two arms intertwined, some cried raising both hands and slapping their heads, some cried covering their heads with ashes and dirt, some cried with disheveled hair covering their faces, some cried pulling out their hair and eyebrows and lowering their heads, some cried raising both hands and crying to the heavens.
Some court ladies, out of grief, ran around in all directions like wild deer shot by poisoned arrows.
Some court ladies covered their faces with their clothes and wailed.
Some court ladies trembled all over like banana leaves swaying in the wind, and wailed.
Some fell to the ground in a faint, barely alive with a little remaining breath, and wailed with a voice.
Some court ladies were like fish out of water, thrown onto land and writhing, with a faint breath and a little remaining life, and wailed weakly.
Some court ladies were like uprooted trees, lying on the ground and rolling around, and wailed.
Such various kinds of suffering afflicted their bodies, and they wailed for the prince.
At that time, the cries of Channa, KÄnthaka, and the countless hundreds of thousands of court ladies could not be heard.
MahÄprajÄpatÄ«, weeping and fainting, regained consciousness and then cried out to the prince, saying:ğŸ”½Alas, my son!
Alas, my son!
When your body was at home, it was anointed with various fragrances, and its majestic virtue was used for adornment;
How is it now that you are in the mountains and valleys, being bitten by mosquitoes, gadflies, and small poisonous insects, able to endure this suffering and remain in the wilderness?
Alas, my son!
Your body was always covered with the fragrance of KÄÅ›i cloth;
How is it now that you are able to endure wearing coarse and foul-smelling clothes?
Alas, my son!
When you were at home, you had pure and wonderful fragrances, a hundred flavors of food, various soups and gruel, and clean white food, and you never put anything bad or mixed in your mouth;
How can you now endure eating coarse, rough, cold, and bland food and drink, either rice or gruel, or porridge or juice? How can you eat this in vain and be able to endure it?
Alas, my son!

When you were in the palace, you had fine, smooth bedding, soft woolen blankets, either covered with heavenly garments, or placed on both sides with pillows to lean on, either lying down or reclining, freely as you wished;
How can you now endure sleeping on the bare ground, or on coarse grass in a clump of thorny needles?
Alas, my son!

When you were at home, you always had servants, or those on the left and right, who constantly served you with a compassionate heart, either leaning on you, kneeling on one knee, or standing on the ground, facing you to observe and serve you, without anything lacking;
How can you now endure those who are angry, or those who are poor and exhausted, who have no compassion towards you, and you can observe and take their intentions?
Alas, my son!
While at home, with your wonderful complexion, delightful and upright, surrounded by a group of maidservants, you enjoyed happiness;
How is it that you are now in the wilderness, like a wild animal, always fearful, sitting and walking alone, and yet find joy in your mind?
Alas, my son!

You were born well, covered by a net, tall and upright, with soft toes and ankles, like a deer king, with soft palms and soles, like lotus leaves, adorned with two wheels, clearly and distinctly visible;

How is it that your footprints are like this, walking barefoot on the ground, with thorns and needles, sand and gravel, sometimes ice and frost, sometimes hot dust, how can you bear to walk back and forth like this?

At that time, MahÄprajÄpatÄ« cried out to the prince in these and countless other ways. Her heart was slightly revived, and she regained her original thoughts. She rose from the ground and asked Chanda,
Chanda!
When my son SiddhÄrtha was leaving, what did he entrust to you?
Chanda!
Who cut off my son's soft, blue-black hair?
Chanda!
Where is my son's hair now?
Chanda replied,
The prince entrusted me with these words:
'Chanda!
When you return home, respectfully bow twice on my behalf to my mother MahÄprajÄpatÄ«. After bowing twice, say this:
'Please inform the great mother not to grieve too much, not to be distressed, and not to think of me;
The prince will soon obtain what he wishes in his heart. Having obtained it, he will return and pay homage to his mother.

The prince's hand pulled out the sword, held the topknot with his left hand, and with his right hand held the sword to cut off the topknot, threw it into the sky, and the gods received it and took it back to the heavenly palace for the sake of making offerings.
At that time, when MahÄprajÄpatÄ« heard what Chanda said, she wept even more bitterly over the prince's topknot, 'Alas, my son!

Your hair is very long, soft and coiled, extremely handsome, with each hair follicle growing a single hair, not disheveled or cut off, suitable for wearing a crown and assuming the throne. How could you bear to cut it off and throw it away?
Alas, my son!ğŸ”½Your two arms are very long, and your gait is leisurely, like a lion king;
Your two eyes are round and full, like an ox king;
His body is golden in color, his chest and shoulders are broad, and his voice is deep like a drum or thunder.
How can such a person be worthy of leaving home and living in the mountains and wilderness?

Now, this land of ours lacks the auspicious signs. If such a person were to practice in accordance with the Dharma, this land would collapse and be unable to rise again, becoming the ruler of the world.
I wish that all virtuous people, endowed with all virtues, will encounter the Dharma King appearing in the world, bringing peace and happiness to the great assembly.'
There is a verse that goes:
'If this land lacks blessings, such a wise person should not be born here.
Since he has already manifested such a virtuous body, he should become the holy ruler of the world.'
At that time, YaÅ›odharÄ cried out loudly, scolding Chanda with a mixed voice of anger and scolding, saying:
'Chanda!
My young wife was sleeping deeply in the middle of the night, unaware of anything. You have now taken away my beloved and cherished sage husband. Where will you take him?
Channa!

How far away is my sage king, the great man, along with you and the horse? The three of you are equal in your actions. Channa and Kanthaka, only the two of you have come alone in front of me, without my beloved sage king. Therefore, my body and mind are trembling now.
Channa!
You are not a good person, you do not benefit me.
Channa!
I now say in earnest, even if it were a cruel and extremely angry enemy, they would still not be able to harm me as much as you have stumbled and fallen me today.
Channa!

If you are the one I take refuge in, you should protect me, you should nurture me. Why do you now see me sleeping in a daze in the middle of the night, and secretly steal away my holy lord, taking him somewhere else?
Channa!
Now you are my greatest enemy. What you have done is already finished. Why do you need to lament and cry anymore?
You should wipe your face. Why bother to grieve in vain, shedding tears from your eyes?
Channa!
Your unwholesome karma is now done. There is no need to grieve.
Channa!
You are my holy husband's good friend. You should restrain your comings and goings, allow what should be done and stop what should not be done;
Now, on the contrary, you have followed along, causing my holy lord to leave as he wished.
Channa!
What use are you?
You have now done this unwholesome deed, and you should be delighted, knowing that you have now gained great rewards and obtained great blessings.
Channa!
Ordinary worldly people would rather take a wise person as their enemy than take a fool as a friend.
Channa!
Although you are a friend to my husband, you have never thought about what you are doing.
Why is it so?
Channa!
You have now done something that is not beneficial to my family, and you should be greatly fortunate.
Channa!
These palaces are lofty and majestic, like a mass of clouds, and are filled with various ornaments and treasures. They are now empty for your sake.
He then spoke a verse to Channa, saying:
Ordinary people would rather be close to a wise enemy than take a fool as a friend,
It is because of your thoughtless actions that our entire family is tormented with suffering.
At that time, YaÅ›odharÄ, having spoken this verse, again said to Chandaka, 'Chandaka!
How can my mind not be sorrowful now?
My husband, if he were here, would be facing us now. These maidservants here, their complexion as white as snow, their lips as red as vermilion, are rare and lovely, most upright and proper.
They should all together enjoy the pleasures of the body.

Who would have known that in a single day he would suddenly become an orphan and a widow? Because of having no master, tears flow from my eyes day and night like a river, and my crying and wailing are constantly unceasing.
Chandaka!
Moreover, this horse has been my enemy for a long time, not bringing me any benefit. Seeing me sleeping in the middle of the night, he carried away the beloved lord in my heart and left the city.
This horse's actions are extremely unwholesome. Why is it now neighing in pain in front of me, filling the entire king's palace with its cries?
When it first took my holy son away, why did this unwholesome horse remain silent, breathing in and out?
If it had neighed like this when leaving, then people would have heard its cries and woken up, and I would not have seen such great suffering now.
This unwholesome horse, even if shot with arrows piercing its body or killed with a stick, should not be allowed to leave and go to the mountains and forests.

Therefore, this horse does not bring any benefit to my family. It is precisely because of fear of a few whips and sticks that it has taken my most beloved and supreme holy lord and husband out to the mountains and wilderness.

Now this palace, because it has no master, the halls, rooms, villages, towns, cities, streets, towers, windows, doors, railings, half-moon-shaped halls, exquisite and marvelous, most supreme and splendid, are all now empty. Because of this horse king AÅ›varÄja, it makes my royal inner quarters like a wilderness. Looking up and down the ground, there is nowhere to crave.'
When YaÅ›odharÄ spoke these many kinds of bitter, painful, sorrowful, choked-up words, it was unhearable and invisible, and she temporarily stopped due to confusion and faintness.
When Chanda heard YaÅ›odharÄ's words, he lowered his head, held his breath, joined his ten fingers, shed tears, and cried out loudly to the noble lady YaÅ›odharÄ, saying:
You should not scold Kaá¹‡á¹­haka now, nor should you scold me in anger.
I am not at fault, and neither Kaá¹‡á¹­haka nor I are guilty.
The night when your noble husband first left, I made many kinds of obstacles, namely by crying out.
At that time, I called out to you in a loud voice, using various words, saying:ğŸ”½Great lady, rise quickly!
Great lady, awaken quickly!
Tonight, the husband you love in this palace wants to take me and Kaá¹‡á¹­haka away.

Holding the hair in his hand, he showed each strand to YaÅ›odharÄ, saying, This hair was pulled out by me from a certain maid at that time. This is the hair of a certain maid, and this is the hair of another maid.
He named each one and told her.
At that time, she was not aware, and all the other maids were the same.
This horse Kanthaka also created obstacles when the Holy Prince left. It neighed more than a thousand times, kicked the ground with its hooves, and would not move forward or backward.
It also shook its head, stretched its nose, and neighed.
When this horse neighed, its voice was heard up to half a yojana away, and the sound of its hooves was heard for one kroÅ›a.
At that time, I called out to the queen and said:
The one you love has left tonight.
The queen and the other court ladies did not notice such sounds, and moreover, the gods concealed them with their spiritual powers so that they could not be heard.
Great queen, you should know!
I and Kanthaka truly dare not take the holy prince away.
Do you understand this calculation? Do you accept my words?
If the holy prince acts in accordance with my words, this will never happen.'
Then he spoke a verse to the queen:
'I now cannot bear to let my tears flow, I join my palms and lower my head to further consult,
The queen truly should not scold the horse, And should not be angry with me.
'Great queen!
I also knew in the past that King Åšuddhodana had a strict order, that all attendants should be very careful and guard the prince.
Although I knew beforehand that there would be such teachings, I was not free. The power of the gods was strong, confusing my mind and intentions, and I could not do as I wished.
What the prince does is all by the power of the gods. It is said that he should leave home.
At that time, I thought, the city gates opened by themselves. Those palace gates have always been guarded by many thousands of people, but they were all careless and did not wake up.
The prince first left the palace gate, like the sun just rising, emitting great pure light, breaking through all darkness.
At that time, I myself knew that this was done by the gods.
Great queen!
At that time, when the prince left the city and was on his way, I was at the very front, walking on foot.
At that time, my body did not feel tired. Great queen!ğŸ”½Great queen!
When this horse Kanthaka was walking on the road, its hooves did not touch the ground, just like when a person is carried along. When it made a sound, it was also not heard from afar.
Great queen!
At that time, I privately thought to myself, and also knew that this was done by the gods.
Great queen!

At that time, the holy prince, in accordance with the Dharma, happily wore the saffron-colored robes of an ascetic. He begged for them from others, took off his own clothes and gave them to others, cut off his topknot and threw it into the sky, where it did not fall to the ground, but was received by the gods.
At that time, I thought to myself and knew that this was done by the gods.
Great queen!
For this reason, the queen should not give rise to anger and resentment towards us.
Why is it so?
It is not because of me, nor is it because of the horse, that the holy prince was taken out.
At that time, the chief consort YaÅ›odharÄ lay on the ground, and after thinking for a while, she wept and wailed with various words, saying:
Alas, my lord!
Why is it that now, when I act in accordance with the Dharma and am filial and obedient to my husband, you abandon me and leave?
Those who seek the Dharma from him will not find the true Dharma, because he is unable to practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Alas, my lord!
Have you not heard that in the past, when kings wished to go to the mountains and forests to seek the Dharma, they took their wives and children with them?
Those kings did not obstruct the holy path and were able to accomplish it.
Alas, my lord!
How could you not know of such a Dharma?

The people still shave their heads together with their wives, go forth to practice the path, diligently cultivate austerities, and will make offerings to the gods with fine horses and hold an unrestricted gathering. In the future, the two will equally receive the supreme fruit of retribution.
If you know the Dharma taught in the Veda treatises, why do you now alone hoard the Dharma by my side and not practice the Dharma together?
Alas, alas, in vain going, in vain born among humans.
If you know that the world together has affectionate love for women, why abandon them?
If you want to be born in the Thirty-three Heavens, craving for the celestial maidens, I now see such things, what is there to crave in those celestial maidens?
What is there that is upright?
What is there that is joyful and happy in the five desires?

If he does not crave for that happiness, abandons this kingly status, majestic virtues, and all of us court ladies, and after giving it up, goes forth and enters the empty and secluded mountains and forests to practice austerities, then I will not accept heavenly rewards, nor envy the heavenly jade women's bodies. I am content, I have this power, I am here, not needing to be born in the heavens. But right here, I will practice austerities and make this vow:

Whether in the human realm or in the heavens, I only wish to serve a lord like you. His mind is resolute, his intentions are so firm. If he abandons us and enters the empty mountains and secluded forests, my mind will be the same, steadfast and unmoving, no different from a rock, the most solid and true.

If it is as I am now, a wife without a husband, and seeing my master leave the house and go to the mountains and forests, leaving me alone and single in an empty room, how can I bear it without my heart bursting?
' Then she spoke a verse, saying:
'My body and mind are now very hard, like iron and stone, no different,
My master has left and entered the mountains, the palace is empty, why does my heart not break now?'
'At that time, Yashodhara, because of this cause and condition, was greatly distressed and her mind became confused. She suddenly fell to the ground.

After a while, she got up again. Sometimes she raised her voice and wept sorrowfully, sometimes she silently lowered her head and pondered, sometimes she suddenly became startled and spoke wildly, saying:ğŸ”½'Where has my husband gone now?
Where is my holy lord staying now?

You have left me alone in the palace, abandoned me, turned your back on me and left. From this day on, if I do not obtain the Holy Son, I will not lie down on my bed, nor will I bathe with fragrant water, nor will I adorn myself, nor will I massage and anoint myself with oil and powder, nor will I wear colorful clothes.

From now on, I will not wear various kinds of necklaces and ornaments, nor will I perfume my body with incense and flowers, nor will I eat fine food, nor will I drink fine beverages, nor will I drink any alcohol at all, nor will I eat the best food as before.

The white hair on my head will no longer be groomed. Although I am in the house, I will always think of it as a mountain forest, and will practice austerities. Until I see that supreme and excellent great man, I will see all the gardens, forests, ponds, springs, and palaces filled with dust, just like a wilderness, no different.
Because of the absence of the sage's son, all the palaces and all the towers have lost their luster, like a desert.

Because of this sorrowful and distressed state of mind, unable to maintain herself, losing her right mindfulness, having no more shame or embarrassment, YaÅ›odharÄ lay on the ground, rolling around in distress and speaking these crazed words. At that time, all the palace ladies present cried out in unison, wailing loudly with tears filling their faces.
There is a verse that goes:
Thus afflicted by such distress, the ladies and queen YaÅ›odharÄ,
Gazing at each other with tears flowing, like heavy rain in the height of summer.
At that time, Channa, seeing YaÅ›odharÄ in such distress, remonstrated, saying:
'Great queen!
Do not give rise to such intense sorrow and distress, do not be greatly saddened, you should stop for a while, do not think of the Holy Son.
When the Holy Son was born, although he was in the human realm, he was no different from a god, his majestic spiritual power was no different from that of a god.

When the Holy Son was born, the gods surrounded him, on the right were the Brahma Kings and their retinue, on the left were Indra and the thirty-three celestials and their retinue, in the east was the Gandharva King Dhá¹›tarÄá¹£á¹­ra, in the south was the KumbhÄá¹‡á¸a King VirÅ«á¸haka, in the west was the NÄga King VirÅ«pÄká¹£a, and in the north was the Yaká¹£a King VaiÅ›ravaá¹‡a, surrounding him to the left and right.

Their bodies were all clad in vajra armor, some holding bows and arrows, some holding spears and halberds, some appearing in front of the Holy Prince to show him the road, some guarding the Holy Prince from behind, some on the left, some on the right, following him as he went.

In the sky above, there were always countless hundreds of thousands of heavenly maidens, all greatly delighted, their bodies filled with joy, unable to contain themselves, bringing various heavenly flowers to scatter upon the Holy Prince, scattering them again and again.

At that time, the Holy Prince, seeing those heavenly maidens, did not feel joyful or happy in his mind, did not love or hate them, did not grasp or touch them. The Holy Prince's mind was like this, not attached to what they used.
Great queen of the country!
When the Holy Prince left, the gods manifested such spiritual powers, and all the offerings to the Holy Prince, I now find difficult to describe in detail one by one.
Having said this, the second queen, the noble lady Gautami, was like a large tree with a broken branch drooping down, unable to support itself.

The noble lady Gautami suffered greatly for the prince. Her mind was poisoned with distress, burned by the hot fire of sorrow, trembling all over, lying on the ground, rolling around and crying loudly, uttering these words:
Alas, my lord!
Your mind is always joyful.
Alas, my lord!
Your face is like a full moon.
Alas, my lord!
You are upright and rare.
Alas, my lord!
Supreme and excellent, endowed with all characteristics.
Alas, my lord!
Your pure body is unmatched in the world, your limbs are not deficient, and you were born in stages, like a golden image.
Alas, my lord!
Your virtues are most excellent.
Alas, my lord!
You are greatly compassionate, revered by gods and humans.
Alas, my lord!
You are valiant and powerful, like NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, with no rival, able to subdue others.
Alas, my lord!
Your Brahma voice is subtle and wonderful, like the sound of a kalaviá¹…ka bird.
Alas, my lord!
Your fame is heard far and wide.
Alas, my lord!
You are adorned with a hundred kinds of blessings and virtues, unequaled in the world of humans and gods.
Alas, my lord!
Your merits are perfect, and all the sages who see you are delighted.
Alas, my lord!
Your fame is revered in the upper, lower, and four directions, and you are a gathering of offerings, like a forest of wisdom.
Alas, my lord!
In the world, your tongue and taste are supreme.
Alas, my lord!
Your lips are red like a bimba fruit.
Alas, my lord!
Your two eyes are dark and radiant, like blue lotus flowers.
Alas, my lord!
His mouth has forty teeth, pure and clean, white like milk, silk, snow, or frost.
Alas, my lord!
His nose is high, prominent, and straight, like cast gold.
Alas, my lord!
The white tuft between his eyebrows is pure and still.
Alas, my lord!
His shoulders are round and thick, broad and even, his waist slender and long, like a bow or quiver, his hands and feet are soft.
Alas, my lord!
His calves, shins, arms, and elbows are like an elephant's trunk, his hands and feet are even, and his nails are all red.
Alas, my lord!
These ornaments were made by the sun, under the auspices of an auspicious star and constellation. When the great King Åšuddhodana made them, he was filled with great joy;
Why is it now that we are separated?
I too do not wish to see these ornaments now.

At that time, GautamÄ«, with a sorrowful mind, was frightened and alarmed again and again, just like a wild deer being chased by others and falling into a trap. Holding a knife and spear, or a bow and arrow, they shot at her body, causing great pain. She ran around in all directions, looking everywhere, with no one able to save and protect her.

At that time, GautamÄ«'s mind was also like this. Her words were not correct. She searched through the palace, east, west, south, and north, but could not find him. She cried out in grief, tears streaming down her face. There was no one to save and protect her. She suffered greatly and cried out loudly, saying:
The prince is here!

This place is just like the palace of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, no different in any way. All the things are complete, just like the majestic and powerful Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, with blazing radiance;
Now, having lost everything, with the sudden disappearance of the Holy Prince, the city is like a charnel ground, like a mountain wilderness, like a vast desert.
Here in the palace, together with the Holy Prince, I experienced incomparable bliss, gave rise to great joy, and had no aversion;
Now, without the Holy Prince, my mind is not attached to it, just as a fish or turtle, leaving the water and living on land, has no temporary joy, let alone mental pleasure.
I am also like this, without the Holy Prince, what joyful mind can there be?
Just as bees have no joy after spring passes, because there are no flowers, they do not cling to that grove, do not crave that tree;
I am also like this now, without the Holy Prince, what joy can there be in this inner chamber?
Alas, my lord!
Wherever you sit or stand, you always make sounds. The palace ladies, with joyful minds, perform great singing and dancing;
Now, this palace is of one kind, without distinction, yet it causes me to suddenly give rise to sorrow and suffering, with an unhappy mind and thoughts, let alone music?
Alas, my lord!

Your body is adorned with various wonderful fragrances and flowers, adorned with necklaces, anointed with fragrant paste and powdered incense, supplied with everything in a timely manner, lacking nothing, you should rightly enjoy pleasures, be satisfied and delighted, why did you suddenly abandon and leave?
It is like a great cloud formation rising in the sky, with lightning and thunder roaring, releasing a great hail storm, suddenly disappearing;
The prince is also like this, next to inherit the throne, he should enjoy pleasures, lacking nothing, yet he abandoned and left.

It must be that in the past, after making exquisite offerings, my mind gave rise to regret, and because of the regretful mind, I now receive this retribution. Although I enjoy immeasurable profound goodness, I suddenly lose it again. Because of the karma of regret, I now become a widow. I have little merit and have lost such a supreme and excellent person.
Alas, this love and affection will not last long, and in an instant it will be lost, just like a play where there is great joy, but suddenly it is over and dispersed.

The present situation is like this, and it is also heard that in the past, a royal sage practiced tranquility, controlled the senses, attained meditation, went to that empty forest, stopped all killing, with the body devoted to austerities, ate various wonderful medicines and sweet fruits, hid in the mountains and forests, and together with his wife practiced celibacy;
Now, for what reason, alone heading to the wilderness, diligently cultivating himself?'
At that time, GautamÄ« embraced Kaá¹‡á¹­haka's head and raised her voice in loud weeping, 'Alas, Kaá¹‡á¹­haka!
The merciless horse, together with you, at one time gave birth to the sage's son, where is he now?
Why did you take him away in the middle of the night, without telling me and letting me know?
' She reproached Chanda, saying these words:
'Alas, you Chanda!
You have no compassion at all. Since I was sleeping, why didn't you wake me up?
Since he is the one I love in my heart, now suddenly leaving, why didn't you tell me to know?
Causing me to sleep and sit alone for a long time, it is truly great suffering.
Alas, you Channa!
Discuss and explain for me, when the Holy Son left, how did he go?
Who led him out?
In this palace, who guided him out?
Which direction did he go?
Where has he gone now?'
After Queen GopÄ« had scolded and reprimanded Channa like this, she again spoke to Channa in a soft and gentle voice, saying:
'Since the matter has already happened, you good Channa!

You personally sent him away, you know where the Holy Son is. Take us to him. We will follow the Holy Son and practice austerities, single-mindedly seeking the Way, hoping to be reborn together with the Holy Son in the heavens.

At that time, Channa, having heard GautamÄ«'s various angry and joyful words, his heart became despondent, and his sorrow and distress doubled. The intense pain and agony overwhelmed his body, and tears flowed down his face. With great self-control, he comforted GautamÄ«'s mind and said these words:
May the queen listen well!
Do not worry,
